awd_titl_txt: Nanomanufacturing of Hierarchical Metallic Glasses as High-performance Electrocatalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a strong need for high performance catalysts in energy-related technologies such as fuel cells and batteries to meet the growing energy demands across the globe and reduce dependence on fossil fuels. Catalysts in energy storage and conversion devices promote the key electrochemical reactions that determine their efficiency, durability and cost. Most of these applications require that the catalysts have large surface area paired with suitable chemistry to facilitate the reaction kinetics. Despite progress at various levels, a versatile nanomanufacturing technology that can meet the necessary requirements of high catalytic activity, durability and cost effectiveness is lacking. This award will investigate a new paradigm of metallic nanostructure catalysts for use in a number of energy conversion and storage applications. Together with the basic research, an education program will be developed to provide training and research opportunities to graduate students, undergraduates, and high school students. Special efforts will be made to encourage women and under-represented minority students to participate in the research, which will improve their retention in science and engineering. The concept, theory, and results will be used in strengthening existing and creating new undergraduate and graduate level courses. The success of this project will provide a transformative approach for scalable nanomanufacturing of metallic-glass catalysts for clean energy conversion and storage technologies such as fuel cells, batteries, and water splitting systems.

The objectives of this research are to study fundamental mechanisms of catalytic activity for metallic glass nanostructures, and to create scalable and low-cost approaches for nanomanufacturing high-performance amorphous catalysts for energy conversion and storage technologies. Metallic-glasses are attractive as high-performance electrocatalysts because of their metastable structure, tunable chemistry, and availability in a wide range of compositions. Despite these unique attributes, the application of metallic glasses has been impeded by the limited ability to produce high-quality catalysts. This research will develop a novel process that directly transforms conventional metals into high-performance hierarchical nanocatalysts. In addition, simulations of the metallic-glass surface morphology and chemistry and their effect on catalytic activity will be carried out using first-principles methods. The integration of experiment and computation to determine electro-catalytic activity will speed up the search for the best metallic glass catalysts, provide better understanding of the catalytic phenomena, and uncover new reaction mechanisms.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Multifunctional materials with hierarchical substructures and desirable surface chemistry are critical for breakthroughs in energy conversion and storage technologies. Next generation electrocatalysts are needed to promote electrochemical reactions to drastically improve their efficiency and durability, while reducing cost associated with the constituent noble metals. Current materials and manufacturing strategies use precious metals as well as expensive templates and precursors, which result in limited functionality and poor durability under typical operating conditions. State of the art catalysts used in energy conversion technologies are plagued by dissolution and poisoning, which continue to be major roadblocks in their performance. To address these limitations, the current project was aimed at overcoming of the technical barriers associated with nanomanufacturing of next generation electrocatalysts based on amorphous alloys and fundamental scientific understanding of their electro-catalytic behavior. Metallic glasses with multiple atomic constituents and tunable surface characteristics offered solutions to a number of these challenges in energy processes and revealed transformative research directions. Facile and scalable electrodeposition approaches were utilized in this project for manufacturing of model metallic glasses and systematically demonstrate the effect of alloy chemistry on their catalytic activity. The hierarchical amorphous alloys were shown to catalyze important reactions such as hydrogen and methanol oxidation. The integrated approach of scalable synthesis, detailed surface characterization, and molecular modeling helped in fundamental scientific understanding of the reaction mechanisms and correlating the atomic distribution with electrochemical activity of model metallic glass systems. Amorphous alloys with little or no noble metal content were synthesized in various hierarchical morphologies to achieve large electrochemical surface area. Density functional theory calculations helped explain the charge transfer mechanisms and steps involved in the electrochemical reactions. Electronic structure modification and synergistic effects were demonstrated for the alloy constituents along with site-specific mapping of electrocatalytic activity. The project provided education, training, and professional development opportunities for several undergraduates and graduate students at the University of North Texas, which is a Carnegie tier-1 research university and a minority serving institution (MSI). The students got the unique opportunity to learn a wide range of topics including advanced manufacturing, clean energy technologies, metallurgical science, and catalysis. The principal investigator and students made presentations and organized workshops for middle and high school students to motivate them towards careers in advanced manufacturing. Several students in the project worked with industrial partners and collaborators, getting valuable exposure to opportunities beyond the university curriculum. The results from the project were disseminated to communities of interest in the form of journal publications as well as presentations at prestigious international conferences.


Last Modified: 06/13/2022
Modified by: Sundeep Mukherjee
